thread.title: Yankees’ rotation battle not going the way Joe Girardi hoped
thread.title_full: Yankees’ rotation battle not going the way Joe Girardi hoped | New York Post

author: George A. King III
title: Yankees’ rotation battle not going the way Joe Girardi hoped
text:
TAMPA — Adam Warren is the only member of the five-man-for-two-spots-rotation competition who is a lock to make the Yankees.
“Outside of Warren, who isn’t going anywhere because he can go to the pen or be in the rotation, the rest of the guys have flexibility and options,’’ general manager Brian Cashman said. “Now we have two weeks to focus on that and make a decision.’’
Luis Severino and Bryan Mitchell, Tuesday night’s starter against the Red Sox, were considered the pre-camp favorites for the spots, but Severino has underwhelmed and Mitchell hasn’t separated himself from the others. So, the door remains open for Luis Cessa and Chad Green.
“I hope sooner than later, but it’s not really ironing out that way,’’ manager Joe Girardi said of naming the fourth and fifth starters. “Some guys have had some struggles. Your hope is that someone would step up and dominate, but it hasn’t been that way.
Mitchell worked 4 ¹/₃ innings in a 4-2 loss to the Red Sox, allowing two runs in the third inning.
“He was OK. You look at the line score and it was OK. He gave up some hard-hit balls,’’ Girardi said of Mitchell, who surrendered seven hits and fanned seven. “I thought he could have used his curveball a little bit more effectively, he had a good curveball.’’
Mitchell said he was pleased with the outing.
“As far as everything I thought it was the best stuff I have had throughout the outings,’’ Mitchell said. “I actually got a few outs on the splitter.’’
Cessa gave up a run, two hits and walked two in two frames and could be headed for Triple-A Scranton/Wilkes-Barre to provide rotation depth.
Dellin Betances said he wasn’t sure when he would pitch for the Yankees next, but didn’t hesitate when asked about being ready for Opening Day.
“I am ready for the season to start,’’ Betances said Tuesday at George M. Steinbrenner Field after returning from playing with the Dominican Republican team in the World Baseball Classic. “I am ready to go.’’
Dellin Betances Charles Wenzelberg Betances last worked Saturday and said the experience of playing for the D.R. won’t soon leave him.
“I am not going to lie. I thought it was more than expected,’’ Betances said. “The crowds in Miami were intense. The crowd was definitely on our side in Miami. It was a very intense crowd from the first inning to the ninth inning. San Diego was fun even though we came up short.’’
Betances had a choice to play for the USA or the Dominican, and said it was a difficult decision. How he was received by the Dominican’s fans made him feel good.
“The love I got from the Dominican fans was unbelievable,’’ said Betances. “I didn’t think it would be like that but a lot of people, the Dominican fans were happy I chose to play for them.’’
Chris Sale might be new to the Yankees-Red Sox rivalry, but he is a quick learner.
Sale made the long ride from Fort Myers to Tampa to face the Yankees to get a taste of the scene.
“Anytime you can get as close as you can to a regular-season game with the atmosphere, the intensity, the energy level, you like to do that, so I was glad I came up here,’’ Sale said after striking out 10 in six innings in which he gave up two runs and four hits. 
“Anybody who knows anything about sports knows about Boston and New York. Even from the outside looking in you can sense the competitive drive in these teams. Coming here playing against the Yankees, at their park, night game, gives it more of a regular-season feel.’’
Clint Frazier went head over heels over the right-field wall chasing a foul ball.
“It is not the first time I have collided with a wall,’’ said Frazier, who landed on his back but wasn’t injured. “I was not going full speed so I braced myself. It was a lot more graceful than it looked.’’
Matt Holliday’s solid spring continued when the DH hit an opposite-field homer to right off lefty Chris Sale in the sixth inning. It was Holliday’s fourth spring homer.
